The Acronyms screen allows you to visualize most common acronyms used in scuba diving.

You can Search, Sort by Headers and scroll down and up.

You cannot edit any of the acronyms.

The Backup screen allows you to backup the application settings and the entire database.

You will find the XML backup file in your Download folder with a name similar to \'airDa Sat Feb 19 14_55_31 EST 2022.xml\'.

You can export this file to a different device and import it using Menu/Maintenance/Restore.

The Calculate Altitude screen allows you to calculate the theoretical depth and safety stop depth at altitude.

The formulas are:

SP = exp(5.255876 * log(1 – (C * A)))
TD = D * (1 / SP) * (SWA / (SWA or FWA))
SSD = 15 ft * (SP / 1) * ((SWA or FWA) / SWA)

Where:

SP = Surface Pressure in atm
C = 0.0000068756 / 1 ft
A = Altitude in ft
TD = Theoretical Depth in ft
D = Depth in ft
SWA = Sea Water ata 33 ft
FWA = Fresh Water ata 34 ft
SSD = Safety Stop Depth in ft

You must enter all variables in order to calculate the altitude.

Clicking the Double Arrow will convert all the variables to the other unit.

The Metric formulas are:

SP = exp(5.255876 * log(1 – (C * A)))
TD = D * (1 / SP) * (WFW / (WFW or WSW))
SSD = 5 m * (SP / 1) * (WFW / (WFW or WSW))

Where:

SP = Surface Pressure in atm
C = 0. 000022558 / 1 m
A = Altitude in m
TD = Theoretical Depth in m
D = Depth in m
WFW = Weight Fresh Water 1.0 kg / l
WSW = Weight of Sea Water 1.0252959 kg / l
SSD = Safety Stop Depth in m

According to the decompression models, the pressure ratio R for altitude diving is the same as the one for ocean diving.\n\nThe standard pressure at sea-level is 1013.25 mbar.\n\nWarm air decreases the atmospheric pressure while cold air increases the atmospheric pressure.

\"A law stating that the pressure of a given mass of an ideal gas is inversely proportional to its volume at a constant temperature.\"

\"For any gas at constant temperature, the volume of the gas will vary inversely with the pressure\".

The Calculate Boyle\'s Law screen allows you to calculate the pressures and volumes.

The formula is:

P1 * V1 = P2 * V2

Where:

P1 = Pressure 1 in psi
V1 = Volume 1 in ft3
P2 = Pressure 2 in psi
V2 = Volume 2 in ft3

You need three (3) of the variables in order to calculate the fourth one.

Clicking the Double Arrow will convert all the variables to the other unit.

Clicking the different buttons or the colored labels will calculate the corresponding variable.

The Metric formula is:

P1 * V1 = P2 * V2

Where:

P1 = Pressure 1 in bar
V1 = Volume 1 in l
P2 = Pressure 2 in bar
V2 = Volume 2 in l

The Calculate Buoyancy screen allows you to calculate the volume needed to lift an object.

The Calculate Buoyancy also allows you to calculate the maximum weight needed to hold a floating container neutral. As an example, if you want to hold a bottle of Coke upside down to practice your aim with a speargun. If the container is a heavy glass container like a Johny Walker bottle (please don\'t break it!), the weight needed will be less than the calculated maximum weight.

"Any object wholly or partly immersed in a fluid is buoyed up by a force equal to the weigh of the fluid displaced by the object".

The formula is:

BN = (OW - (OD * (WSW or WFW))) / (WSW or WFW)

Where:

BN = Buoyancy Needed in ft3
OW = Object Weight in lb
OD = Object displacement in ft3
WSW = Weight of Sea Water 63.92623 lb / ft3
WFW = Weight of Fresh Water 62.421 lb / ft3

You must enter the Weight and the Object Displacement of the object in order to calculate the Buoyancy Needed.

You must enter the Object Displacement in cubic feet of the floating container in order to calculate the maximum Object Weight needed to hold the floating container neutral.

Clicking the Double Arrow will convert all the variables to the other unit.

Clicking Calculate or the colored label will calculate the Buoyancy Needed.

The Metric formula is:

BN = (OW - (OD * (WSW or WFW))) / (WSW or WFW)

Where:

BN = Buoyancy Needed in l
OW = Object Weight in kg
OD = Object displacement in l
WSW = Weight of Sea Water 1.0252959 kg / l
WFW = Weight of Fresh Water 1.0 kg / l

\"A law stating that the volume of an ideal gas at constant pressure is directly proportional to the absolute temperature.\"

\"For any gas at a constant pressure, the volume of the gas will vary directly with the absolute temperature or for any gas at a constant volume, the pressure of the gas will vary directly with the absolute temperature\".

The Calculate Calculate Charles Law screen allows you to calculate the volumes, pressures and temperatures.

The formulas are:

Calculating volume at constant pressure:

V1 / V2 = T1 / T2

Calculating pressure at constant volume:

P1 / P2 = T1 / T2

Where:

V1 = Volume 1 in ft3
V2 = Volume 2 in ft3
P1 = Pressure 1 in psi (absolute)
P2 = Pressure 2 in psi (absolute)
T1 = Temperature 1 in F + 460 Rankine
T2 = Temperature 2 in F + 460 Rankine

You need three (3) of the variables in order to calculate the fourth one.

Clicking the Double Arrow will convert all the variables to the other unit.

Clicking Calculate or the colored labels will calculate the corresponding variable.

The Metric formulas are:

Calculating volume at constant pressure:

V1 / V2 = T1 / T2

Calculating pressure at constant volume:

P1 / P2 = T1 / T2

Where:

V1 = Volume 1 in l
V2 = Volume 2 in l
P1 = Pressure 1 in bar (absolute)
P2 = Pressure 2 in bar (absolute)
T1 = Temperature 1 in C + 273 Kelvin
T2 = Temperature 2 in C + 273 Kelvin

The Calculate Current screen allows you to calculate the current based on the time it takes for an object to travel a distance.

The formula is:

C = D / T / 1.687810

Where:

C = Current in knot
D = Distance in feet
T = Time in second

You need both variables in order to calculate the current.

Clicking the Double Arrow will convert all the variables to the other unit.

Clicking Calculate or the colored labels will calculate the corresponding variable.

The Metric formula is:

C = D / T / 0.51444

Where:

C = Current in knot
D = Distance in meter
T = Time in second

The Calculate Current Deviation screen allows you to calculate the drift deviation due to the current.

You need all three variables, Distance, Swim Speed and Current Speed in order to calculate the deviation.

You can click on "Swim Speed" and "Current Speed" labels to calculate the corresponding swimming speed and the current speed.

The Calculate Current Deviation screen will give you a degree correction to add or subtract to your compass.

If your heading is 300 degrees, the current deviation is 30 degree and the current is coming from your left, swimming upstream means subtracting 30 degrees or heading 270 degrees.

If your heading is 300 degrees, the current deviation is 30 degree and the current is coming from your right, swimming upstream means adding 30 degrees or heading 330 degrees.

Clicking the Double Arrow will convert all the variables to the other unit.

Clicking Calculate or the colored labels will calculate the corresponding variable.

The Calculate Cylinder screen allows you to convert cylinder size from Imperial to Metric and vice versa.

The formulas are:

To Metric:

atm = RP / 14.6959
LV = RV / atm
MV = LV * 28.3168

Where:

RP = Rated Pressure in psi
LV = Liquid Volume in ft3
RV = Rated Volume in ft3 e.g. 80 ft3
MV = Metric Volume in l

To Imperial:

LV = MV * 0.0353147
atm = RP / 14.6959
RV = atm * LV

Where:

LV = Liquid Volume in ft3
MV = Metric Volume in l e.g. 11.1 l
RP = Rated Pressure in psi
RV = Rated Volume in ft3 e.g. 80 ft3

Clicking the Double Arrow will convert all the variables to the other unit.

Clicking Calculate or the colored labels will calculate the corresponding variable.

\"A law stating that the pressure exerted by a mixture of gases in a fixed volume is equal to the sum of the pressures that would be exerted by each gas alone in the same volume.\"

\"The total pressure exerted by a mixture of gases is equal to the sum of the pressures of each of the different gases making up the mixture, with each gas acting as if it alone was present and occupied the total volume\".

The Calculate Dalton\'s Law screen allows you to calculate the partial pressure, the fraction of the gas in %, the MOD (Maximum Operating Depth) or the END (Equivalent Narcotic Depth).

The Nitrox formula is:

Pg = Fg * P

Where:

Pg = Partial pressure of the gaz in ata. e.g. 1.4
Fg = Fraction of the gas in %. e.g. .32
P = Total pressure. Feet transformed in ata. e.g. 111.3 ft into 4.4 ata

You need two (2) of the variables in order to calculate the third one.

The Trimix formulas are:

FO2 = PPO2 / Depth in ata
FN2 = (END in ata * 0.791) / Depth in ata
FHe = 1.0 - FO2 - FN2

Where:

PPO2 = Partial pressure of the O2 in ata. e.g. 1.4
FO2 = Fraction of the O2 in %. e.g. .23
FHe = Fraction of the He in %. e.g. .24
FN2 = Fraction of the N2 in %. e.g. .53
Depth = Depth of the dive in feet transformed in ata. e.g. 164 ft into 6 ata
END = Equivalent Narcotic Depth in feet transformed in ata. e.g. 99 ft into 4 ata

You can set your preferred END in Settings under the Depths category.

You can optimize your Best Mix so your calculated END is below your desired END.

You need two (2) of the variables in order to calculate the third one. Both % O2 and % He are interpreted as one variable and are both required to calculate the PPO2 and the MOD.

Clicking the Double Arrow will convert all the variables to the other unit.

Clicking the different buttons or the colored labels will calculate the corresponding variables, the PPHe (in red if >= 4.25) and the PPN2.

The Metric Nitrox formula is:

Pg = Fg * P

Where:

Pg = Partial pressure of the gaz in bar. e.g. 1.4
Fg = Fraction of the gas in %. e.g. .32
P = Total pressure in bar. e.g. 34 m into 4.4 bar

You need two (2) of the variables in order to calculate the third one.

The Metric Trimix formulas are:

FO2 = PPO2 / Depth in bar
FN2 = (END in bar * 0.791) / Depth in bar
FHe = 1.0 - FO2 - FN2

Where:

PPO2 = Partial pressure of the O2 in bar. e.g. 1.4
FO2 = Fraction of the O2 in %. e.g. .23
FHe = Fraction of the He in %. e.g. .24
FN2 = Fraction of the N2 in %. e.g. .53
Depth = Depth of the dive in meter transformed in bar. e.g. 50 m into 6 bar
END = Equivalent Narcotic Depth in meter transformed in bar. e.g. 30 m into 4 bar

The Calculate Descent/Ascent screen allows you to calculate the time it takes to ascent or descent based on a descent/ascent rate and a depth.

The formula is:

T = D / DAR

Where:

T = Time in min.
D = Depth in ft
DAR = Descent / Ascent Rate in ft/min.

You must enter the Depth and the Rate in order to calculate the Time.

Clicking the Double Arrow will convert all the variables to the other unit.

Clicking Calculate or the colored label will calculate the time to Ascent or Descent.

The Metric formula is:

T = D / DAR

Where:

T = Time in min.
D = Depth in m
DAR = Descent / Ascent Rate in m/min.

The Calculate EAD screen allows you to calculate the Equivalent Air Depth.

The formulas are:

FN2 = 100.0 - FO2 - FHe
EAD = ((FN2 * (D + (SWA or FWA))) / 79.1) - (SWA or FWA)

Where:

FN2 = Nitrogen in %
FO2 = Oxygen in %
FHe = Helium in %
EAD = Equivalent Air Depth in ft
D = Depth in ft
SWA = Sea Water ata 33 ft
FWA = Fresh Water ata 34 ft

You must enter the FO2 and the Depth in order to calculate the Equivalent Air Depth (EAD).

Clicking the Double Arrow will convert all the variables to the other unit.

Clicking Calculate or the colored label will calculate the EAD.

The Metric formulas are:

FN2 = 100.0 - FO2 - FHe
EAD = ((D + (WSW or WFW)) * (FN2 / 79.1)) - (WSW or WFW)

Where:

FN2 = Nitrogen in %
FO2 = Oxygen in %
FHe = Helium in %
EAD = Equivalent Air Depth in m
D = Depth in m
WSW = Weight of Sea Water 1.0252959 kg / l
WSW = Weight of Fresh Water 1.0 kg / l

The Calculate END screen allows you to calculate the Equivalent Narcotic Depth.

The formula is:

END = ((D + (FSW or FFW)) * (1 - (he / 100))) - (FSW or FFW)

Where:

END = Equivalent Narcotic Depth in ft
D = Depth in ft
FSW = Feet of Sea Water 33 ft
FFW = Feet of Fresh Water 34 ft
he = Helium content in %

You must pick the right Salinity, enter the percent of He and the Depth in order to calculate the Equivalent Air Depth (EAD).

Clicking the Double Arrow will convert all the variables to the other unit.

Clicking Calculate or the colored label will calculate the END.

The Metric formula is:

END = ((D + (WSW or WFW)) * (1 - (he / 100))) - (WSW or WFW)

Where:

END = Equivalent Narcotic Depth in m
D = Depth in m
WSW = Weight of Sea Water 1.0252959 kg / l
WSW = Weight of Fresh Water 1.0 kg / l
he = Helium content in %

The Calculate Gas Conversion screen allows you to convert psi into cubic feet and vice versa.

The formulas are:

TF = TV / RP
P = V / TF
V = P * TF

Where:

TF = Tank Factor in ft3 / psi
TV = Tank Volume in ft3
RP = Rated Pressure in psi
p = Pressure in psi
V = Volume in ft3

You need three (3) of the variables in order to calculate the fourth one.

Clicking the Double Arrow will convert all the variables to the other unit.

Clicking Calculate or the colored label will calculate either the Pressure or the Volume Available.

The Metric formulas are:

TF = TV / RP
P = V / TV
V = P * TV

Where:

TF = Tank Factor. n/a in metric
TV = Tank Volume in l
RP = Rated Pressure. n/a in metric
p = Pressure in bar
V = Volume in l

The Calculate Nitrox screen allows you to blend Nitrox/EANx gas.

The upper portion is not used. Only the bottom portion starting with Start and Desired are used for this version.

Start Pressure may be 0. Desired Pressure must be specified.

Both Start Mix and Desired Mix must be greater or equal to 20.9%.

Calculate Start will calculate an optimized Start Pressure to obtain the desired mix.

Calculate Desired will calculate the O2 and top-off pressure to obtain the desired mix.

The message Cannot blend that mix will be displayed if it is impossible to blend the desired mix.

Clicking the Horizontal Double Arrow will convert all the variables to the other unit.

The Calculate Pressure screen allows you to calculate the absolute pressure.

The formulas are:

D = (ata - 1) * (FSW or FFW)
ata = (D / (FSW or FFW)) + 1
P = ((D / (FSW or FFW)) + 1) * 14.6959

Where:

D = Depth in ft
ata = Atmosphere absolute
FSW = Feet of Sea Water 33 ft
FFW = Feet of Fresh Water 34 ft
P = Pressure in psi

You must pick the right Salinity, enter either the depth or the ata in order to calculate the Pressure.

Clicking the Double Arrow will convert all the variables to the other unit.

Clicking Calculate or the colored label will calculate the Absolute Pressure.

The Metric formulas are:

D = (bar - 1) * (HPSW or HPFW)
ata = ((D / (HPSW or HPFW)) + 1) Same as P
P = ((D / (HPSW or HPFW)) + 1) Same as ata

Where:

D = Depth in m
ata = Atmosphere absolute in bar
HPSW = Hydrostatic Pressure of Sea Water 10.0 bar/10 msw
HPFW = Hydrostatic Pressure of Fresh Water 10.3 bar/10 msw
P = Pressure in bar

The Calculate RMV screen allows you to calculate your RMV, Bottom Time, Pressure (Used or Needed) as well as Volume Used (or needed) in Imperial and Metric unit and Vice Versa by clicking the Double Arrows.

The formulas are:

TF = TV / RP
SAC = (P / T) / ata
SAC = ((V / TF) / T) / ata
RMV = SAC * TF
T = P / (SAC * ata)
T = (V / TF) / (SAC * ata)
P = SAC * ata * T
V = RMV * ata * T

Where:

TF = Tank Factor in ft3/psi
TV = Tank Volume in ft3
RP = Rated Pressure in psi
SAC = Surface Air Consumption in psi / min.
RMV = Respiratory Minute Volume in ft3 / min.
ata - Atmosphere absolute
T = Time in min.
P = Pressure in psi
V = Volume in ft3

To calculate your RMV, enter all of the necessary fields (RMV can be present or not) and click the RMV button.

It will also convert your RMV to the other unit if all the other unit necessary fields are provided. This is the only field that is automatically converted among the calculations.

To calculate your Bottom Time, enter all of the necessary fields (Bottom Time can be present or not) and click the Time button.

To calculate your Pressure (Needed), enter all of the necessary fields (Pressure can be present or not) and click the Pressure button. Does not take into account the minimum pressure needed at the end of the dive.

If you supply all of the fields, you can calculate your Volume Used (or Needed) by clicking the Volume button.

Clicking the Double Arrow will convert all the variables to the other unit.

Clicking the different buttons or the colored labels will calculate the corresponding variable.

Example

How much gas do I need for a dive of 20 minutes at 100 fsw with a RMV of 0.5 ft3/min?

Volume (ft3) = RMV (ft3/min) * ata * time (minute)

Where:

RMV = 0.5 ft3/min
ata = (100 / 33) + 1
ata = 4.03
Volume = 0.5 ft3/min * 4.03 * 20 min
Volume = 40.3 ft3

PS It does not account for the volume needed to go down, go up and do the safety stop

The Metric formulas are:

TF = TV / RP
SAC = (P / T) / ata
SAC = ((V / TV) / T) / ata
RMV = SAC * TV
T = P / (SAC * ata)
T = (V / TV) / (SAC * ata)
P = SAC * ata * T
V = RMV * ata * T

Where:

TF = Tank Factor. n/a in metric
TV = Tank Volume in l
RP = Rated Pressure. n/a in metric
SAC = Surface Air Consumption in bar / min.
RMV = Respiratory Minute Volume in l / min.
ata = Atmosphere absolute
T = Time in min.
P = Pressure in bar
V = Volume in l

The Swimming Distance screen allows you to calculate either the Distance, Kicks or the Time it takes to swim.

The Swimming Distance can be calculated using Dist/Kick * Kicks or using Swim Speed * Time.

The formulas are:

D = DPK * K
D = S * T
DPK = D / K
K = D / DPK
K = (S * T) / DPK
S = D / T
S = (DPK * K) / T
T = D / S

Where:

D = Distance in ft
DPK = Distance Per Kick in ft / Kick
K = Kick
S = Speed in ft / min.
T = Time in min.

Clicking the Double Arrow will convert all the variables to the other unit.

Clicking the different buttons or the colored labels will calculate the corresponding variable.

The Metric formulas are:

D = DPK * K
D = S * T
DPK = D / K
K = D / DPK
K = (S * T) / DPK
S = D / T
S = (DPK * K) / T
T = D / S

Where:

D = Distance in m
DPK = Distance Per Kick in m / Kick
K = Kick
S = Speed in m / min.
T = Time in min.

The Calculate Trimix screen allows you to blend Trimix (Helium, O2 and air) gas. Nitrogen is only contain in the air.

The upper portion is not used. Only the bottom portion starting with Start and Desired are used for this version.

Start Pressure may be 0. Desired Pressure must be specified.

Calculate Start will calculate an optimized Start Pressure to obtain the desired mix.

Calculate Desired will calculate the O2 and top-off pressure to obtain the desired mix.

The message Cannot blend that mix will be displayed if it is impossible to blend the desired mix.

Clicking the Horizontal Double Arrow will convert all the variables to the other unit.

Clicking the Vertical Double Arrow will switch the values between O2 and He. This can be useful when the O2 bank is low.

The Calculate Unit Conversion screen allows you to convert Imperial unit to Metric unit and Vice Versa by clicking the Double Arrows.

The formulas are:

From Imperial to Metric
A = A * 1.01325
D = D * 0.3048
P = P * 0.068948
T = (TF - 32) * (5.0 / 9.0)
V = V * 28.3168
W = W * 0.453592

From Metric to Imperial
A = A * 0.98692
D = D * 3.28084
P = P * 14.503774
T = (TC * (9.0 / 5.0)) + 32
V = V * 0.0353147
W = W * 2.20462

Where:

A = ata in ata or bar
D = Depth in ft or m
P = Pressure in psi or bar
T = Temperature
TF = Temperature Fahrenheit
TC = Temperature Celsius
V = Volume in ft3 or l
W = Weight in lb or kg

Clicking Calculate or the colored labels will calculate the corresponding variable.

The Compare Dives screen allows you to select up to 3 dives and compare the different numbers.

You can Minimize (- Minus sign), Maximize (+ Plus sign) or go back to the Original Dive Plan by clicking Plan.

The different labels are:
- LBN: Log Book Number
- Cylinder: Cylinder Type
- Volume (ft3): Total volume of your cylinder(s)
- Average Depth (ft): Average depth of your dive
- SAC (psi/min): Surface Air Consumption
- RMV (ft3/min): Respiratory Minute Volume
- Pressure Start (psi): Pressure in your cylinder(s) at the start of the dive
- RT (min): Running Totals in minutes
- RT (psi): Running Totals in psi
- RT (ft3): Running Totals in cubic feet
- Pressure End (psi): Pressure in your cylinder(s) at the end of the dive
- Volume End (ft3): Volume in your cylinder(s) at the end of the dive

The Constants screen allows you to visualize most common constants used in scuba diving.

You can Search, Sort by Headers and scroll down and up.

You cannot edit any of the constants.

Found a bug? Please send the details at MyAirBuddyAndI@gmail.com with the mention "Bug" in the subject.

Have suggestions! Please send them to MyAirBuddyAndI@gmail.com with the mention "Suggestion" in the subject.

Thank you and safe diving!

The team at My Air Buddy And I

The Edit a Cylinder screen allows you to create a Cylinder or edit an existing Cylinder.

The required fields are Type, Volume, and Rated Pressure.

The default values are the values coming from the Menu, Maintenance, Cylinder Type list. Also, today\'s date are the default for the Last VIP and Last Hydro dates

Adding a Cylinder adds it to your inventory of Cylinders and makes it available to build your Equipment Groups.

The Pick a Cylinder screen allows you to select a Cylinder to add in your Equipment Group.

The Rated Pressure (RP) shows up when flipping the phone in Landscape mode.

They are no restriction on the Cylinder you pick. The same Cylinder can be part of many Equipment Groups. The In Group column indicates in which Equipment Group the Cylinder is already part of, if any.

Removing a Cylinder from an Equipment Group keeps the Cylinder in your Cylinder inventory, ready to be picked to build another Equipment Group.

Click and select Detail to edit a Cylinder.

Click the Floating Action Button to add a Cylinder.

Longclick to enter the multi delete mode.

The Edit a Cylinder Type screen allows you to create a new Cylinder Type or edit an existing Cylinder Type.

Type: The first set of letters "AL/HP/LP" means Aluminum/High Pressure/Low Pressure. The second set of letters represent the volume in cubic feet (ft3). If needed, a letter A, B, will differentiate cylinders with similar properties.

Description: The first set of letters "AL/ST" means Aluminum/Steel. The second set of letters represent the volume in cubic feet (ft3). The last set of numbers represents the rated pressure in psi.

The required fields are Type, Description, Volume and Rated Pressure.

The default values are 80.0 ft3 for the Volume and 3000 psi for the Rated Pressure.

Cylinder Type identifier e.g. AL80 cannot be modified. The workaround is to make sure it is not being used anywhere by the application, delete it and add a new one.

The Pick a Cylinder Type screen allows you to select a Cylinder Type.

The first set of letters "AL/ST" means Aluminum/Steel. The second set of letters represent the volume in cubic feet (ft3). The last set of numbers represents the rated pressure in psi.

Click and select Detail to edit a Cylinder Type.

Click the Floating Action Button to add a Cylinder Type.

Longclick to enter the multi delete mode.

All the Cylinder Types cannot be all deleted, you need at least one valid Cylinder Type.

Note: For this release you can change the description of the types but it is best not to add any new types.

The Edit a Diver screen allows you to create a new Diver or edit an existing Diver.

The required fields are Last Name or First Name and Maximum Depth Allowed.

The default values are Man for the Gender, January 1st minus 25 years for the Birth Date and 60 ft for the Maximum Depth Allowed.

The Pick A Diver screen allows you to select a Diver for your next planning.

Click and select Detail to edit a Diver.

Click on Group to see and edit the Diver\'s equipments.

Click the Floating Action Button to add a Diver.

Longclick to enter the multi delete mode.

The Edit Consumption screen allows you to quickly edit the Consumption for your Dive.

The required fields are Beginning Pressure (BP), Ending Pressure (EP), Oxygen (O2), Nitrogen (N) and Helium (He).

For the Beginning Pressure (BP), for Double, since the pressure equalizes itself between both cylinders, just enter the psi form your Submersible Pressure Gauge (SPG) at the beginning of the dive.

For the Beginning Pressure (BP), for Sidemount, calculates the average psi from both SPG before your Dive

For the Ending Pressure (BP), for Double, since the pressure equalizes itself between both cylinders, just enter the psi form your SPG at the end of the dive.

For the Beginning Pressure (BP), for Sidemount, calculates the average psi from both SPG after your Dive

The default values are the Rated Pressure from the Cylinder Type as the Beginning Pressure, 21 for the Oxygen (O2), 79 for the Nitrogen (N) and 0 for the Helium (He).

The sum of the Oxygen (O2), Nitrogen (N) and Helium (He) must equals 100.

The Pick Consumption screen allows you to Pick and Edit the Consumption for your Dive.

You cannot Add or Delete a Consumption.

You can only Pick and Edit a Consumption.

The Extra Diver(s) screen allows you to select extra Diver(s) other than your primary buddy. e.g. An Instructor, Dive Master or Dive Guide who wants to enter the diver(s) that she or he dove with.

Click on Detail to edit a Diver.

Click the Floating Action Button to add a Diver.

Longclick to enter the multi delete mode.

The Edit a Dive screen allows you to create a new Dive or edit an existing Dive.

For any Dive the required fields are Status, Dive Type, Salinity, Log Book No. (must be between 0 and 9999), Date and Time In and Altitude (can be zero).

For a Dive Status of Plan the required fields are SAC, RMV and Planning.

For a Dive Status of Real the required fields are Bottom Time, Average Depth and Consumption.

The default values are Plan for the Status, Dive Type, SAC and RMV as selected on the SAC and RMV screen, the last Log Book No. + 1 for the Log Book No., Today\'s date or the Last Dive date for Date, Now for Time In and 0 for the Altitude.

Click No Buddy to add your first Diver. Click the Diver\'s name to add or pick another one.

You can remove yourself from a Dive to add a Dive to your Buddy, without affecting your numbers. Just click the minus sign on the left of Me. It is possible to add you back on the Dive at anytime. Just click the plus sign on the left of Me.

You can remove your Buddy from a Dive to dive solo. Just click the minus sign on the right of your Buddy\'s name. It is possible to add a Buddy back at anytime. Just click the No Buddy link.

Click Pick an Equipment Group to select your Equipment Group and your Buddy\'s Equipment Group.

The RMV cannot be at 0.0 to plan a Dive. The Buddy\'s RMV is required if a Buddy is selected.

The SAC and RMV are calculated using the Bottom Time and the Average Depth from the dive computer for a Dive of status Real.

Click the = icon to calculate the SAC and RMV without having to Save the Dive.

Click Consumption to enter and edit the air consumption for both you and your Buddy.

Click Planning to enter your Dive Segment(s) for your Dive.

Click Extra Diver(s) to enter extra diver(s) other then your buddy.

All the Dive, Equipment Group, Cylinder, Planning and Consumption, Extra Diver(s) info will be save only after clicking the Save button.

The Pick A Dive screen allows you to add or select a Dive for your planning.

Click and select Detail to edit a Dive, show the Turnaround Pressure, Rule of Thirds pressure, the Minimum Pressure or the Emergency Pressure for a Dive.

You can Compare Dives by selecting the Check Box (not to be confused with the multi delete mode) on this list and compare them for a selected pressure type. e.g. Turnaround Pressure, Rule of Thirds pressure, the Minimum Pressure or the Emergency Pressure.

Click the Floating Action Button to add a Dive.

Longclick to enter the multi delete mode.

The Edit a Dive Plan screen allows you to create a new Dive Plan or edit an existing Dive Plan.

The required fields are Time, Depth and Order No.

The default values the last Order No. + 10 for the Order No, 0 min. for the Time and 0.0 ft for the Depth.

Enter your Time in minute at depth, most likely your Non Decompression Limit (NDL).

The Order No. allows you to move your Dive Segment up or down.

The Pick A Dive Plan screen allows you to see and edit all of the Dive Plan for your dive.

Click and select Detail to edit a Dive Plan.

Click the Floating Action Button to add a Dive Plan.

Longclick to enter the multi delete mode.

The Edit a Dive Type screen allows you to create a new Dive Type or edit an existing Dive Type.

The required fields are Type, Description and Sort Order.

The default value is 0 for the Sort Order.

No Dive Type identifier can be modified. The workaround is to make sure it is not being used anywhere by the application, delete it and add a new one.

The Pick a Dive Type screen allows you to select a Dive Type.

Click and select Detail to edit a Dive Type.

Click the Floating Action Button to add a Dive Type.

Longclick to enter the multi delete mode.

The Dive Type Last, Average, Minimum and Maximum cannot be deleted nor modified, they are reserved for the application.

Note: For this release you can change the description of the types but it is best not to add any new types.

This graphic shows the Drift Pressure for a Log Book No. and a given minimum cylinder psi set in the Settings, My minimum Pressure. e.g. 500 psi, as planned.

This graphic is helpful in situations where the Dive Master says "I don't want to see anyone coming up with less than 500 psi in their cylinder!".

If air and bottom temperatures are specified for the dive, beginning pressure will be adjusted according to Charles\' law.

It shows the Running Descent RD, Running Totals RT and the Running Ascent RA in time, pressure and volume, located between the dive flag ang the buoy.

It shows the Ascent pressure to complete the dive with all of the Deep Stop and Safety Stop, with the correct Descent and Ascent rates to surface with the minimum cylinder pressure.

The lowest Ascent pressure between you and your buddy, if any, will be shown in red.

Clicking your Buddy will show your Buddy's graphic. Clicking Me will show your graphic.

Clicking the Minus sign minimizes the Bottom Time to fit within the dive parameters. Clicking Plan shows the original plan. Clicking the Plus sign maximizes the Bottom Time to fit within the dive parameters.

Bottom time is optimized to be the same for both divers. Your are supposed to dive with your buddy after all! For that reason, it is possible that the Ending Pressure might be higher for one of the diver.

The Bottom Time maybe optimized to max out the cylinder pressure.

On the right side of the right anchor line and at the top of the bottom line, the beginning pressure and the ascent rate of the Ascent is shown.

On the left side of the right anchor line, all of the Ascent and Bottom Time from the Planning are shown with their respective Descent rates.

On the right side of the anchor line, the Deep Stop and Safety Stop are shown with their respective ascent rates.

It is using the SAC and RMV specified in the Edit a Dive screen. In case of discrepancies, RMV has precedence over SAC.

A warning is shown if your buddy or yourself do not have enough air to complete this dive.

This graphic shows the Emergency Pressure for Log Book No.

This graphic helps you determine if your Emergency cylinder has enough air capacity to bring you safely to the surface.

If air and bottom temperatures are specified for the dive, beginning pressure will be adjusted according to Charles\' law.

It shows the Running Ascent RA and the Running Totals RT both in time, pressure and volume, located between the dive flag ang the buoy.

The lowest Ending pressure between you and your buddy, if any, will be shown in red.

All calculations are performed with your Working SAC and RMV. If no Working SAC and RMV are found then the default set in Settings, SAC and RMV, Minimum SAC and Minimum RMV are applied.

Clicking your Buddy will show your Buddy's calculations. Clicking Me will show your calculations.

You can remove the Deep Stop and Safety Stop (Not recommended) by clicking Shorten. Clicking the Complete label will include the Deep Stop and Safety Stop (Recommended).

If you have only one Emergency cylinder, you can calculate your Emergency Gas for both divers by clicking Both. Clicking Single will reset the calculations for the previously selected diver.

On the left side of the anchor line, the starting pressure of the Emergency cylinder is shown.

At the bottom left of the anchor line, an Out Of Air (OOA) situation is shown. It represent the time needed to assess the Out Of Air (OOA) situation and exchange regulators. It is added at the end of the return portion, if the Out of Air (OOA) situation occurs at the deepest depth with the least air capacity in the cylinders.

On the right side of the anchor line and at the top of the bottom line, the beginning pressure and the ascent rate of the Ascent is shown.

On the right side of the anchor line, the Deep Stop and Safety Stop are shown with their respective ascent rates.

It is using the SAC and RMV specified in the Edit a Dive screen. In case of discrepancies, RMV has precedence over SAC.

A warning is shown if your buddy or yourself do not have enough air to bring you safely to the surface.

The Edit an Equipment Group screen allows you to create a new Equipment Group or edit an existing Equipment Group.

The Rated Pressure (RP) shows up when flipping the phone in Landscape mode.

The required fields are Type, Description and Usage.

The default value is Single for the Type and Bottom Gas for the Usage.

The different Usage are Bottom Gas (to go down, dive and come backup), Travel Gas (extra cylinders to extent your Bottom Time), Decompression Gas or Stage Gas (to perform your deco or deep deco), Emergency Gas (for emergency ascent).

The Cylinder List section allows you to select a Cylinder for your Equipment Group.

The same Cylinder can be part of many Equipment Groups but the same Cylinder cannot be in an Equipment Group more than once.

Click on Usage to change it.

Click and select Detail to edit a Cylinder.

Click the Floating Action Button to pick a Cylinder.

Longclick to enter the multi delete mode.

The Pick an Equipment Group screen allows you to select an Equipment Group for your next planning.

Click and select Detail to edit an Equipment Group.

Click the Floating Action Button to add an Equipment Group.

Longclick to enter the multi delete mode.

You can find more help at https://mmarin1m.github.io/en/Add_Equipment.pdf

The Edit a Group Type screen allows you to create a new Group Type or edit an existing Group Type.

The required fields are Type and Description.

They are no default value.

No Group Type identifier can be modified. The workaround is to make sure it is not being used anywhere by the application, delete it and add a new one.

The Pick a Group Type screen allows you to select a Group Type.

Click and select Detail to edit a Group Type.

Click the Floating Action Button to add a Group Type.

Longclick to enter the multi delete mode.

Only User Defined Group Type can be deleted. If no User Defined Group Type exists, no delete check box will be showing.

Note: For this release you can change the description of the types but it is best not to add any new types.

This Home screen displays the Dive data used on the last Dive of status Real or the Dive Type and its average consumption you selected on the RMV screen.

Click on Me to edit your information. Click on your Buddy\'s name to edit his or her information.

It shows the Dive Type, the Group (Equipment Group), the RMV (Respiratory Minute Volume) for you and your buddy, you last used.

After the initial install, the defaults are Average for Dive Type, No Group for the Group (Equipment Group) and 0.0 for the RMV for both divers.

When selecting a Dive of status Real, the Group (Equipment Group) shows with its name, and the real values for the RMV for both divers.

To Date shows your Total Dive Time in hh:mm:ss to date for both you and your buddy, if present.

Last Dive shows the date of your last dive for both you and your buddy, if present.

Surface Interval shows your surface interval in Day(s) and HH:MM after the completion of your last dive for both you and your buddy, if present.

Only numbers from Dive of status Real are considered.

You can find more help at https://mmarin1m.github.io/en/Quick_Start.pdf

You can find the Privacy Policy at

My Air Buddy And I Privacy Policy

The Restore screen allows you to select a backup file and restore the application settings and the entire database.

You will find the XML backup file in your Download folder under with a name similar to \'airDa Sat Feb 19 14_55_31 EST 2022.xml\'.

The RMV (Respiratory Minute Volume) screen allows you to pick the type of dive you are planning to do, select your Buddy and pick a Dive Type.

Click No Buddy to add your first Diver. Click the Diver\'s name to pick another one.

When applicable, the number of Dives used for the average is showing between ().

The Dive Type Last represents the last Dive. Click on it to see the details on the dive.

The Dive Type Average represents the average of all Dive Types.

The Dive Type Minimum represents the smallest RMV of all your Dives. Click on it to see the details on the dive.

The Dive Type Maximum represents the highest RMV of all your Dives. Click on it to see the details on the dive.

The Dive Type Resting is used to calculate your air consumption during decompression stops.

The Dive Type Swam is used to calculate your air consumption during a swim, at a constant depth, constant speed and for a given time.

The Dive Type Work is used to calculate your air consumption during a major effort, at a constant depth, constant speed and for a given time.

Each Dive Type represents the average of all the Dives for the same Dive Type.

Click the Floating Action Button to add your first Dive or to pick an existing Dive.

After the initial install, the RMV is set at 0 and the Dive Type at Average.

Only numbers from Dive of status Real can be considered.

This graphic shows the Minimum Pressure for a Log Book No.

If air and bottom temperatures are specified for the dive, beginning pressure will be adjusted according to Charles\' law.

It shows the Running Descent RD, Running Ascent RA and the Running Totals RT both in time and in volume, located between the dive flag ang the buoy.

This graphic shows the absolute minimum amount of gas you need to get both yourself and your buddy safely to the surface from the deepest point of the dive while you are both breathing off of the smallest cylinder and/or the diver\'s cylinder with the worst RMV.

The lowest Minimum Turnaround pressure between you and your buddy, if any, will be shown in red.

Clicking your Buddy will show your Buddy's graphic. Clicking Me will show your graphic.

On the left side of the anchor line, all of the Descent and Bottom Time from the Planning are shown with their respective Descent rates.

At the bottom right of the anchor line, the last Bottom Time from the Planning is split in two. The first part represent the forward portion. The second part represent the return portion with the Turnaround pressure.

Both Bottom Times may be optimized to max out the cylinder pressure.

A Turnaround Time equivalent to the Settings, Turnaround Time is included between the last two (2) Bottom Times.

At the bottom left of the anchor line, an Out Of Air (OOA) situation is shown. It represent the time needed to assess the Out Of Air (OOA) situation and exchange regulators. It is added at the end of the return portion, if the Out of Air (OOA) situation occurs at the deepest depth with the least air capacity in the cylinders.

Starting with the Out Of Air (OOA) situation, all calculations are performed with your Working SAC and RMV. If no Working SAC and RMV are found then the default set in Settings, SAC and RMV, Minimum SAC and Minimum RMV are applied.

On the right side of the anchor line and at the top of the bottom line, the beginning pressure and the ascent rate of the Ascent is shown.

On the left side of the right anchor line, all of the Ascent and Bottom Time from the Planning are shown with their respective Descent rates. The red marker will be on the right side of the anchor line.

On the right side of the anchor line, the Deep Stop and Safety Stop are shown with their respective ascent rates.

It is using the SAC and RMV specified in the Edit a Dive screen. In case of discrepancies, RMV has precedence over SAC.

A warning is shown if your buddy or yourself do not have enough air to complete this dive.

This graphic shows the Rule of Thirds Pressure for a Log Book No.; One-third of your gas supply for going inward, one third for the dive out and one third in reserve for emergencies.

This graphic is helpful in situations where the dive occurs in an overhead environments such as cave and wreck dives.

If air and bottom temperatures are specified for the dive, beginning pressure will be adjusted according to Charles\' law.

It shows the Running Descent RD, Running Ascent RA and the Running Totals RT both in time and in volume, located between the dive flag ang the buoy.

It shows the Rule of Thirds pressure to complete the dive with all of the Deep Stop and Safety Stop, with the correct Descent and Ascent rates to surface with one third of your beginning pressure left in your cylinder. You do not need to end the dive, but you should leave this depth and ascend to a shallower part of the dive. Please don"t dive to the limits but within the limits.

The lowest Turnaround pressure between you and your buddy, if any, will be shown in red.

Clicking your Buddy will show your Buddy's graphic. Clicking Me will show your graphic.

On the left side of the anchor line, all of the Descent and Bottom Time from the Planning are shown with their respective Descent rates.

At the bottom right of the anchor line, the last Bottom Time from the Planning is split in two. The first part represent the forward portion. The second part represent the return portion with the Turnaround pressure at exactly one third of the beginning pressure. It is possible that the time shown will have a negative value.

A Turnaround Time equivalent to the Settings, Turnaround Time is included between the last two (2) Bottom Times.

On the right side of the anchor line and at the top of the bottom line, the beginning pressure and the ascent rate of the Ascent is shown.

On the left side of the right anchor line, all of the Ascent and Bottom Time from the Planning are shown with their respective Descent rates. The red marker will be on the right side of the anchor line.

On the right side of the anchor line, the Deep Stop and Safety Stop are shown with their respective ascent rates.

It is using the SAC and RMV specified in the Edit a Dive screen. In case of discrepancies, RMV has precedence over SAC.

A warning is shown if your buddy or yourself do not have enough air to complete this dive.

The Edit a Segment Type screen allows you to create a new Segment Type or edit an existing Segment Type.

The required fields are Type and Description.

They are no default value.

No Segment Type identifier can be modified. The workaround is to make sure it is not being used anywhere by the application, delete it and add a new one.

The Pick a Segment Type screen allows you to select a Segment Type.

Click and select Detail to edit a Segment Type.

Click the Floating Action Button to add a Segment Type.

Longclick to enter the multi delete mode.

Only User Defined Segment Type can be deleted. If no User Defined Segment Type exists, no delete check box will be showing.

Note: For this release you can change the description of the types but it is best not to add any new types.

This graphic shows the Turnaround Pressure for a Log Book No. and a given minimum cylinder psi set in the Settings, My minimum pressure. e.g. 500 psi, as planned.

This graphic is helpful in situations where the Dive Master says "I don't want to see anyone coming up with less than 500 psi in their cylinder!".

If air and bottom temperatures are specified for the dive, beginning pressure will be adjusted according to Charles\' law.

It shows the Running Descent RD, Running Ascent RA and the Running Totals RT both in time and in volume, located between the dive flag ang the buoy.

It shows the Turnaround pressure to complete the dive with all of the Deep Stop and Safety Stop, with the correct Descent and Ascent rates to surface with the minimum cylinder pressure.

The lowest Turnaround pressure between you and your buddy, if any, will be shown in red.

Clicking your Buddy will show your Buddy's graphic. Clicking Me will show your graphic.

Clicking the Minus sign minimizes the Bottom Times to fit within the dive parameters. Clicking Plan shows the original plan. Clicking the Plus sign maximizes the Bottom Times to fit within the dive parameters.

Bottom times are optimized to be the same for both divers. Your are supposed to dive with your buddy after all! For that reason, it is possible that the Ending Pressure might be higher for one of the diver.

On the left side of the anchor line, all of the Descent and Bottom Time from the Planning are shown with their respective Descent rates.

At the bottom right of the anchor line, the last Bottom Time from the Planning is split in two. The first part represent the forward portion. The second part represent the return portion with the Turnaround pressure.

Both Bottom Times may be optimized to max out the cylinder pressure.

A Turnaround Time equivalent to the Settings, Turnaround Time is included between the last two (2) Bottom Times.

On the right side of the anchor line and at the top of the bottom line, the beginning pressure and the ascent rate of the Ascent is shown.

On the left side of the right anchor line, all of the Ascent and Bottom Time from the Planning are shown with their respective Descent rates. The red marker will be on the right side of the anchor line.

On the right side of the anchor line, the Deep Stop and Safety Stop are shown with their respective ascent rates.

It is using the SAC and RMV specified in the Edit a Dive screen. In case of discrepancies, RMV has precedence over SAC.

A warning is shown if your buddy or yourself do not have enough air to complete this dive.

The Edit a Usage Type screen allows you to create a new Usage Type or edit an existing Usage Type.

The different Usage are Bottom Gas (to go down, dive and come backup), Travel Gas or Stage Gas (extra cylinders to extent your Bottom Time), Decompression Gas (to perform your deep deco or deco), Emergency Gas (for emergency ascent).

The required fields are Type and Description.

They are no default value.

No Usage Type identifier can be modified. The workaround is to make sure it is not being used anywhere by the application, delete it and add a new one.

The Pick a Usage Type screen allows you to select a Usage Type.

The different Usage are Bottom Gas (to go down, dive and come backup), Travel Gas or Stage Gas (extra cylinders to extent your Bottom Time), Decompression Gas (to perform your deep deco or deco), Emergency Gas (for emergency ascent).

Click and select Detail to edit a Usage Type.

Click the Floating Action Button to add a Usage Type.

Longclick to enter the multi delete mode.

Only User Defined Usage Type can be deleted. If no User Defined Usage Type exists, no delete check box will be showing.

Note: For this release you can change the description of the types but it is best not to add any new types.

PLEASE READ this waiver.

In no way will Michel Marin or any other person, but yourself, be responsible for your use of this application. You use any calculations and estimations provided by this application at your own risk, and should perform your own calculations before diving.

This application is provided as is, and without any claims of fitness for purpose. It is provided as a theoretical tool for fast estimations, and must not be used as the sole tool for planning dives.

You are responsible for explaining this agreement to any third party who may use this application on your equipment.

You can read, accept or refuse this waiver any time by clicking Waiver in the main menu.
